description: Recorded since 1579, from quag +‎ mire. The sense “perilous, mixed up and troubled situation” has been recorded since 1775.
Alternatively, the word may apparently be a variation of the earlier quakemire, from quake + mire.

entries.meaning: A swampy, soggy area of ground.
examples: That quagmire regularly ‘swallows’ caught-up hikers’ boots

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A perilous, mixed up and troubled situation; a hopeless tangle.
examples: Synonyms: predicament; see also Thesaurus:difficult situation
The paperwork got lost in a quagmire of bureaucracy.
Those election results are a quagmire for any coalition except one of national union.

verbs.description: quagmire (third-person singular simple present quagmires, present participle quagmiring, simple past and past participle quagmired)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To embroil (a person, etc.) in complexity or difficulty.
